Module img¶

The module img contains the structural functions of the project (the basical elements of it), which are able to, for example, control the Image’s format, create new ones, encode a picture into a matrix…

This is the list of all of it:

img.get_h(img)[source]¶

Returns the image height

Parameters:img (tuple) – Image representation (Type, Matrix)
Returns:The height of the image
Return type:int 
>>> get h(('1', [[255, 255], [255, 255], [255, 255]]))
3
>>> get h(('L', [[255, 255, 255], [255, 255, 255], [255, 255, 255]]))
3
img.get_w(img)[source]¶

Returns the image width

Parameters:img (tuple) – Image representation (Type, Matrix)
Returns:The witdh of the image
Return type:int 
>>> get_w(('1', [[255, 255], [255, 255], [255, 255]]))
2
>>> get_w(('L', [[255, 255, 255, 255, 255], [255, 255, 255, 255, 255]]))
5
img.img(matrix, model)[source]¶

This function has diferent utilities depending on the value of model argument. On one hand, if model = ‘RGB’,’L’ or ‘1’ (the diferent image modes / types), the function verify if the matrix estructure is valid for the selected mode, then returns the image representation (Type, Matrix) of it. If not, the function returns a warning.

On the other hand, if model = ‘DISCOVER’ the function tries to discover the mode of the image from matrix. Unless the matrix has some sintactic mistakes (in which case returns a warning), the function returns the image representation (Type (discovered), Matrix).

Parameters:
  • matrix (list) – Image matrix
  • mode (str) – The mode of the image or the parameter ‘DISCOVER’
Returns:

Image representation (Type, Matrix)
Return type:

tuple

 
>>> img([[255,255,0],[255,128,255],[191,255,255]],'DISCOVER') 
('L', [[255, 255, 0], [255, 128, 255], [191, 255, 255]])
>>> img([[255,255,0],[255,0,255],[0,255,255]],'DISCOVER')
('1', [[255, 255, 0], [255, 0, 255], [0, 255, 255]])
img.is_null(img)[source]¶

Checks if an image (Type, Matrix) is null

Parameters:img (tuple) – Image representation (Type, Matrix)
Returns:True (if it is null) or False (if not)
Return type:bool 
>>> is_null(('NULL', None))
True
>>> is_null(('RGB',[(255,255,255),(255,255,255)]))
False
img.matrix(img)[source]¶

Returns the pixel matrix of the image

Parameters:img (str) – Image’s file name
Returns:The matrix of the image
Return type:list 
>>> matrix('blanc_bn.jpeg')
[[255, 255], [255, 255], [255, 255]]
>>> matrix('blanc_grey.jpeg')
[[255, 255, 255], [255, 255, 255], [255, 255, 255]]
img.mode(img)[source]¶

Retuns the image mode

Parameters:img (tuple) – Image representation (Type, Matrix)
Returns:The image mode
Return type:str 
>>> mode(('1', [[255, 255], [255, 255], [255, 255]])
'1'
>>> mode(('L', [[255, 255, 255], [255, 255, 255], [255, 255, 255]]))
'L'
img.null()[source]¶

Returns an empty image: (‘NULL’, None)

Returns:The null image
Return type:Tuple: (‘NULL’, None) 
>>> null()
('NULL', None)
img.subimg(img, ow, oh, w, h)[source]¶

Returns a sub-region of an image with size (w * h), starting at pixel (ow,oh). Naturally, the sub-image must be fully contained in img. The parameter img must be the name of the picture you want to trim (the path or the file’s name (if the image is in the same directory of the module)). This funciton don’t return anything, only saves the sub-region image as ‘subregion.jpeg’.

Parameters:
  • img (str) – Image’s name (including the format (.jpeg, .png…))
  • ow (int (lower than img horizontal size)) – Horizontal position of the origin pixel
  • oh (int (lower than img vertical size)) – Vertical position of the origin pixel
  • w (int) – Witdh of the subregion
  • h (int) – Height of the subregion
Returns:

None (saves the trimmed image)
img.white_bn(w, h)[source]¶

Returns an image in black and white (‘1’) with all white pixels and size w*h

Parameters:
  • w (int) – The width of the new image
  • h (int) – The height of the new image
Returns:

An all white new image (w * h) in ‘1’ mode
Return type:

tuple, (‘1’, Matrix)

 
>>> white bn(3,3)
('1', [[255, 255, 255], [255, 255, 255], [255, 255, 255]])
>>> white_bn(2,3)
('1', [[255, 255], [255, 255], [255, 255]])
img.white_grey(w, h)[source]¶

Returns an image in grey format (‘L’) with all white pixels and size w * h

Parameters:
  • w (int) – The width of the new image
  • h (int) – The height of the new image
Returns:

An all white new image (w * h) in ‘L’ mode
Return type:

tuple, (‘L’, Matrix)

 
>>> white grey(3,3)
('L', [[255, 255, 255], [255, 255, 255], [255, 255, 255]])
>>> white grey(5,2)
('L', [[255, 255, 255, 255, 255], [255, 255, 255, 255, 255]])
img.white_rgb(w, h)[source]¶

Returns an image in RGB format with all white pixel and size w * h

Parameters:
  • w (int) – The width of the new image
  • h (int) – The height of the new image
Returns:

An all white new image (w * h) in ‘RGB’ mode
Return type:

tuple, (‘RGB’, Matrix)

 
>>> white rgb(3,3)
('RGB', [[(255, 255, 255), (255, 255, 255), (255, 255, 255)], 
[(255, 255, 255), (255, 255, 255), (255, 255, 255)], 
[(255, 255, 255), (255, 255, 255), (255, 255,
